Guy who conquers girls in his video games figures out his skills transfer to real life.
Let's just say that I liked the premise of the story, and I was glad that the shtick didn't get old. However, I hated the filler episodes, which contained no story at all.
The art was fair and sound was good. There's actually some pretty beautiful orchestral background music. I would definitely recommend listening to some of the OST. My favorite was that great track that plays at the moments when Katsuragi "completes" his conquests "Kuchizuke Made no Kyori." I liked it a lot!
Katsuragi himself is a simple character with definedtraits. His value that he adds to the anime is not his character development, but rather his "genius-level" intellect when it comes to gal conquesting. It was entertaining to see how he would handle each new situation. Elsie is a static character for the most part. The heroines themselves were each different and interesting in their own ways. Most of them had realistic problems that weren't TOO cliche.\n\n
The World Only God Knows is similar to One Punch Man in the fact that you know exactly what's going to happen in the end, but you don't know how and when it'll happen. A fair anime with an interesting premise allows for a score of 7.

Overall this is one of my favorite series of all time.

Review: Episodes 1-3
As a show that presents character's flaws and how they overcome them, The World Only God Knows hit near dead-center.
The concept is interesting, but not the best. It is not the best because, first, The World Only God Knows is based on spirits, a very popular concept among Japanese cartoons. This shaves away some of the show's originality. There is mainstream Bleach, masterpiece Spirited Away, also-masterpiece Princess Mononoke, and a lot more. Because of the number of spirit-based shows, The World Only God Knows would be shelved as one of the many spirit-based shows. The story should have based its itself on somethingmore original, which could have made the concept more interesting. But even though the concept is at a loss in terms of originality, the story's focus on the flaws of characters is a plus. Today, many Japanese cartoons are based on a character being pushed into a conflict, receiving a special power, or being the cause of a conflict, etc., and a chosen few are based upon characters. Death Note, Code Geass, and again Bleach are some of the many examples of shows not based on characters (I chose these shows because they are famous and easily to relate). The focus on character is highly original, and outweighs some of the show's unoriginality. In summary, the show's concept is not the best because of a hint of unoriginality, but very interesting because of its originality in a different field. In terms of story, The World Only God Knows hits near dead-center. (Story 8/10)


This show's artwork is pretty, a bit too pretty. The art is not a pain to look at, but its lack of real-ness is a turnoff. Lighting in this show is simply too bright and lacks in shadow and definition. The background is bland, compared to 5 Centimeters Per Second. The World Only God Knows' artwork is a thumbs up, but lacks two things: 1) Effective shadows 2) Detail. To effectively showcase characters, a show's art is vital. (Art 7/10)


Music that is played in this show are not distracting nor do they stand out. (Sound 7/10)


Characters in this show are interesting, but some are not used to their full potential. Each heroine's personalities are shallow (excluding the demon). On the case of the first heroine, we couldn't make out a distinct personality. What we did notice, however, was her dilemma. On the case of the second heroine, we noticed a cliche personality (self-explanatory). In the end, the heroine characters (excluding the demon) are not the best personalities one can think of. The better personalities in this series are the male protagonist and the demon. By their interactions with each other (the male protagonist and the demon), we can easily tell that he wants to move on with a dull life, and that she is highly curious and eager-to-please. These two characters' personalities shine. Being a show that focuses on the flaws of characters, The World Only God Knows does a decent job. (Character 7/10)


Because of the intriguing concept, The World Only God Knows is highly enjoyable when coupled with humor. (Enjoyment 8/10)


Overall, this show is great with some flaws, which is why this show hits near dead-center. (Overall 8/10)

Kami nomi zo Shiru Sekai, shortened as KamiNomi; here is an anime than once caught my sight some time ago. Let me share my thoughts about it and this review. NOTE: I based this review on the first two seasons of the anime since they're quite similar
STORY: 7/10
I may find the story of this anime to be quite an original work, but I don't really find it all that great. Here you have a protagonist who is a gamer yet rejects reality and later finds himself tasked to find and seal loose souls by being romantically intimate with the possessed victim - which are allgirls. It's clear that this is a harem. But I don't dislike it because of that. I'm quite dubious about the main concept here. Nonetheless I was amused by the show by its humor which at some points are clear reference to other anime shows. The story has direction and the romance between characters are depicted very nicely. Oh, there is also some fan-service here and there and were executed adequately. So I assure you that the story won't leave a bad taste in your mouth.


CHARACTERS: 7/10

I really found the characters here lovable. They have colorful personalities and has great development as the story progresses - even our anti-reality protagonist. My personal favorite is Haqua by the way.


VISUAL AND AUDIO QUALITY: 8/10

The visual quality didn't astound me that much as I've seen many iterations of it in different anime shows of the same genre. Nonetheless I found it pretty and the animations run very well in all scenes.

In audio; the seiyuus and their roles are nothing to complain about as they did their jobs well if not perfect. The soundtrack is pleasant and memorable as well


OVERALL: 8/10

It may not be outstanding that it overshadows many anime shows, KamiNomi is still a great anime. It has comedy, romance, lovable characters and a story that will really get your attention. And I can tell that will have a fun experience watching this. But the final verdict is up to depending your preferences.
I think this is such an awesome twist to your usual "harem" type stories unlike many harems it shows a legitimate character advancement in the main character, which surprisingly is keeping me hooked.

It is really hard to tailor a romance anime.
Every other romance anime I've watched seems to think that romance equates to lust and those aforementioned anime fill scenes with flopping breasts instead of actual material. That being said, Kami nomi zo Shiru Sekai (The World God only Knows) goes for the tingling sensation within our hearts and not our no-nos.
The anime is more or less viewed in arcs or small episode series dedicated to individual girls that the main character(Katsuragi Keima) conquers. This idea is a double-edged sword where the pro's are that each girl gets highlighted and the key messages are beautifully projected butthe con is that every time he finishes(haha...stop) we are wanting a little bit more (which is how the author meant it to be). So in a metaphorical sense this anime is a firework not a symphony and for a romance anime that is unheard of because there is very little development of the female(but they do develop the main characters).


The art is good, they very it from normal to detailed to super un-detailed to the tone of the anime to inject either humor or passion. However, they really stand out in their sound. Being in a oddly holy and gaming genre, they use choir and house music which when combined which is oddly enjoyable. The endings are sung by the different girls he conquers and variation like that is fantastic. 


As a gamer myself, I appreciate the gaming references along with the many other references they make in the anime. Although the anime is far from realistic its not absurd which wins lots of Microsoft points from me, too many anime go from funny to stupid and I am proud to say this is not one of them. 


In the end, the anime hits a lot of good points from being innovative to hitting the right points. The authors deserve a nice car or a fire engine.

I had seriously mixed feelings about the subject matter; could a series with such a premise be anything but a farce? It turned out to be less bad than I feared (which was otaku, in the very worst sense). As much as I liked the final episode, and trolling the librarian, and already the rich-girl arc, the rest were so meh... This would be either a 7 or 8, and I guess in honor of the good arcs, I'll make it 8.

Reality is a bad game, even though our generous God made it for us, but still, even God knows that the world is imperfect. Everything is imperfect, even us humans, there is imperfection in us. But the opposite of everything imperfect is the 'Ideal'. Ideals are the vast imaginations of a being that thinks that is the perfect one, such as movies, anime, games and etc.
Keima Katsuragi is the protagonist of this anime and the most developed character. He is the smart one and the galge gamer in his class by his way holding the PFP, cool in a way; but this is his wayto deny the real world and live in the gaming world when he is out of his room. Keima's ideal is that the girls of his games are supposed to be in reality. But in fact, the world is imperfect. 


Elsie is the deuratagonist of this anime, the one who interrupted from Keima to do something for the real world and Keima's little sister, even though he's pissed off because of her actions that made her 'an illegitimate sister'.


Ayumi Takahara, Mio Aoyama, Kanon Nakagawa and Shiori Shiomiya are the hosts of the loose souls, very different and has her own distinct. Ayumi, a track and field runner; Mio, a rich daughter whose lifestyle is rich; Kanon, a convenient star; And Shiori, a bibliophile. Very different parameters, a very good factor of that even them can be a 2-D character in most galge games.


This story has a very interesting hysteria behind its dramatic scenes, even Keima just act for the sake of the girls. The impact of Elsie on the first episode, a sudden event of having loose souls being escaped to the whole world, just very splendid. Even the sound and music, english translations of songs about love, just made this anime an ideal of romance.


Even this anime is a excellent one, a perfect anime must have issues. My issue of Elsie. Yes, she does cooperate at most times, but she never helps Keima of having the loose souls out of the hosts (Except on Rieko's conquest, but that's on the manga). The partner should help the leader, well, I think that partnership is not mostly applied to that.


I was surprised that the first season is finished, seems kinda short (well it is anime) but it is a long journey, I strongly recommend this for most otakus who love romance.

Something I can say about this anime is that it's interesting. It show's you what a hardcore date sim gamer is like, and Keima is some of the best characters you can get in a anime.
The World Only God Knows is a excellent anime, you get what you usually get from a harem, comedy anime, but you also get something extra.
Something that make this anime good is it characters, and you won't find a better duo than Elsie and Keima.
You have Elsie who's a new demon, but she is clueless, happy and cute.
Then you have Keima who is very smart, serious and sometimes stupid ina good way.\n\n
This is something everyone can enjoy, if not you hate harem anime that is.\n
But if you haven't chech this out yet then I would recommend it to you

So I've been following the Kaminomi manga for quite a while. However, this review is about the anime and not the manga, so therefore I'll try not to be too biased (and probably fail miserably).
Story - 8/10.
I like the premise for this series. It's original (from what I know) and it's amusing. Despite this, it's quite... hard to explain to people. In a way, it makes no sense unless you actually watch it. It's not complex or anything, but it's just hard to summarise. Or maybe I'm just stupid.
Art - 9/10.
The art style is lovely. I love the colouring. Also, I didn't spot any majorQUALITY moments so that's good.


Sound - 10/10.


The music is brilliant. From the theme songs (God only knows is one of my favourite anime openings of 2010) to the BGM to the character songs -- it's all amazing. The voice acting is good, too. The only way they could have improved the voice acting was if they replaced everyone with Wakamoto Norio.


Character - 7/10.


To be honest, several of the characters bored me. I don't like Ayumi's type of character, Elcea is annoying and Shiori is too cliché (gotta agree with Keima on the librarian-type girls here). It wasn't horrible writing or anything, but they just didn't interest me. On the other hand, Keima is AWESOME, as is his mum. I also love Mio. And, in a surprise turn of events, I liked anime!Kanon more than manga!Kanon.


Enjoyment - 9/10.


I looked forward to a new episode every week. I liked pretty much all of them, except for a couple (but you get that with every series so it's okay). I got several laughs out of this series.


Overall - 10/10.


This is one of my favourites. Okay, sure, it's not in my list of favourites, but it's up there. Depending on how season 2 is, it might earn a place. I'm highly anticipating season 2 (is it April yet?), because the next few girls are awesome. Especially Tsukiyo.


tl;dr: Go and watch this. It's totally worth it.

The World God Only Knows is about a high school boy who is a god of the gaming world (specifically dating sims) and repels reality.  He one day unknowingly signs a contract with the demon world that requires him to get girls to fall in love with him to capture loose souls.  This is ironic because Katsuragi has only ever captured the hearts of digital or 2-D girls.
There is no plot to be  heavily invested in other than the overall premise.  The plot focuses more on individual stories of the girls that Katsuragi encounters.  These divided story lines reflect onreal world themes and personal issues that a viewer can empathize with.


In regards to characters, I love them all, and they're all extremely entertaining but I  feel as if the main protagonist could be developed a little more.  The priority of character development goes to the numerous girls that Katsuragi has to captivate, therefore it doesn't leave much space for main character growth.  Although saying that, the different story lines subtly reflect of Katsuragi's perspective of the real world.


The art is actually pretty high quality for an anime that doesn't really need intense animation at all.  It's nice and appealing to watch and some scenes that diverge from reality are just beautiful.


As for the sound, I loved the full soundtrack.  The opening was great, and the ending song was amazing as well.  There's nothing I can really say except the music was phenomenal and fit in the with the anime extremely well.


Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed The World God Only Knows.  It's something that's fun and interesting to watch, not something you have to become invested in.  It's entertaining and funny due to the hilarious insights of the characters and their antics, but also in a way enthralling and emotional in its underlying personal issues and themes.

This was actually one of the few rare cases where or read (and sometimes found) the manga first before even touching the anime. I was actually pretty excited when I first found out that there was an anime for it and immediately went to go watch it.
Story - 5/10
The plot in the anime is pretty bland because it ended so quickly. The 12 episodes only consists of a few plotless episodes here and there and the rest focused on Keima capturing females with runaway spirits in them. Still, the story will get some merit because of the whole runaway spirit concept and its originality. Asa reader of the manga, I felt a little disappointed since it ended with only 12 episodes, none of which containing any thick plot at all which only begins to appear later on in the manga.


Art - 8/10


The art is pretty good, not much that I would complain about. The opening is pretty nicely done.


Sound - 8/10


Also pretty good, there isn't really many ways you can screw up on sound.


Character - 5/10


Similar comments given to the story. There's minimal character development because there was such little time to develop it at all.


Enjoyment - 7/10


However, having said all that, I quite enjoyed seeing the first few chapters of the manga in color and sound. I can't say that it was terrible to watch, and it's a little like a collection of one-shots.


Overall - 7/10


I guess if you're planning to watch something short and refreshing, you'd probably enjoy this anime.

-~Story 5/10~-
So, assuming you read this anime's synopsis here on MAL, you know the basic jist of things. For me, the story seemed straightforward and understandable, but bland and far too simple at the same time. 
Here's how I saw the story and plot of the whole anime: Kiema romances girl every two episodes using his skills derived from dating sims, cute nii-san captures "loose souls." And then you just repeat that for 12 episodes.
-~Art 8/10~-
-~Sound 6/10~-
Generally, I'm not ever good with explaining why I "liked the art" or why I "liked the sound" of an anime >.>. I mean, there's no real reason asto why I liked the style of drawing, or style of music used in an anime -- it's all personal preference, and let's be honest, these two don't have that much of an impact on the actual anime, they aren't that important. So, moving on.\n\n
-~Character 5/10~-\n
I'm not so sure I liked a lot of the characters in this anime. I'm also not so sure this anime could be considered a harem either, each girl Kieta meets doesn't stick around for more than two episodes, they just disappear off the face of the world. This means there isn't much room for any development of feelings towards 60% of the vital characters for the anime. The only characters in this anime that you might start to get a feel for is Kiema, Kiema's mom, and cute nii-san.\n
Now, that being said, I'm sure some people will start to get minor emotion towards one of the female roles, but those would quickly be replaced by new emotions after you finish 2 sets of episodes (each pertaining to a different female).\n\n
-~Enjoyment 7/10~-\n
For my personal enjoyment of this anime, I give it a low 7/10. The story's blandness, the lies of harem (grr, was pretty angry about that), and the lack of character build up really made a hard impact on how much I enjoyed the anime. That being said, each episode had me laughing pretty hard -- from Keima being tazed, to baking a cake by sticking it in an oven and cooking the oven over a medieval camp fire. Probably one of the funnier animes I've seen, right next to Kureha Zombie Desuka.\n\n
Overall, I give this anime a high 7/10.\n
If you're into anime with cheesy romance, lots of blushing, cute little sisters, and a lot of comedy, I'd say this is for you.
